core_idea: The document outlines Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which mandates employers to provide earned paid sick leave to employees, including specific provisions for use during public health emergencies like COVID-19. It details employee eligibility, accrual, permissible reasons for leave, employer obligations, enforcement, and anti-retaliation protections to ensure workers can take paid sick leave without penalty. The key concepts include accrual rates, allowable uses of leave, supplemental leave during emergencies, recordkeeping, and employer notification requirements.
initial_content:
Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.
Employee Eligibility
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.
How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.
Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:
The employee:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee needs to care for a family member who:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:
(i) The employee’s place of business; or
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.
Taking Paid Sick Leave
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.
Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.
Paid Sick Leave at Separation
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.
Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):
An employee’s need to:
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(v) Care for a family member who:
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
Or if:
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
Or to:
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;
Or due to:
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.
Recordkeeping
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.
Anti-Retaliation
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.
Notice to Employees
Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers must immediately post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute to employees the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.
Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.
The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.
***
Jackson Lewis attorneys are available to assist employers in their compliance efforts. If you have questions about the HFWA, including the poster and employee notice requirements, revisions to language in employee handbooks, implementation strategies, or any other workplace issues, please contact the Jackson Lewis attorney with whom you regularly work.

optimizations.query: new employment laws in colorado 2023 for small businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado implemented several new employment laws affecting small businesses, with a significant focus on paid sick leave and retirement benefits. Under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), all employers, regardless of size, must provide earned paid sick leave starting January 1, 2022, with employees accruing at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually. This leave can be used for personal or family illness, preventive care, or recovery from domestic abuse, among other reasons. Employers must allow carryover of unused sick leave up to 48 hours but can limit annual use to that amount. Additionally, the law mandates supplemental paid sick leave during public health emergencies, such as COVID-19, providing up to 80 hours for qualifying reasons without requiring documentation. Employers must also reinstate unused sick leave if an employee is rehired within six months [11].

Furthermore, the Colorado Secure Savings Program requires businesses with more than five employees to offer employees access to a retirement plan, ensuring small businesses provide retirement savings options to their workforce [7].

These laws collectively enhance worker protections and benefits in Colorado, positioning the state as a leader in employee rights and small business responsibilities [9][11][7].

The employee:

(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.

(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.

(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;

(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:

optimizations.query: new employee legal requirements in colorado 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In Colorado in 2023, new employee legal requirements include compliance with the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which mandates that all employers provide paid sick leave to employees regardless of employer size. Employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually, and may use this leave for personal or family illness, preventive care, or issues related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment. Employers must allow leave in one-hour increments and cannot require employees to find replacement workers as a condition for taking leave. Unused sick leave can be carried over up to 48 hours to the next year, but payout at separation is not required unless the employee is rehired within six months, in which case accrued leave must be reinstated [11].

Additionally, Colorado implemented paid medical and family leave starting in 2023 under Proposition 118, providing employees with paid leave benefits for medical and family care needs, further expanding employee protections [3].

Employers must also be aware of wage and hour rules, including exemptions from minimum wage and overtime requirements for certain employees, which often depend on salary basis and job duties [10].

Overall, new hires in Colorado in 2023 must be informed of their rights to paid sick leave, family and medical leave benefits, and wage protections under state law, with employers responsible for maintaining compliance and proper recordkeeping [11][3][10].

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.

Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.

The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.

In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;

Pricing for these templates varies widely, from affordable one-time purchases to subscription-based services that include ongoing updates and legal review.

Employers are encouraged to review and update their handbooks regularly to reflect any changes in the law or workplace practices. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;

(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;

(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or

optimizations.query: current state laws on mandatory sick leave for businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
State laws on mandatory sick leave for businesses vary significantly across the United States. Many states have enacted laws requiring employers to provide paid sick leave, while others have no such mandates, and some prohibit local governments from imposing their own sick leave requirements.

For example, California has a well-established mandatory paid sick leave law requiring employers to provide paid sick leave to employees, with specific accrual and usage rules [8][9]. Similarly, Maryland and Michigan have passed statewide mandatory paid sick leave laws, with Maryland’s law taking effect in early 2018 and Michigan becoming the 11th state to approve such legislation in 2018 [4].

Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) requires employers to provide up to 48 hours of earned paid sick leave annually, with accrual beginning immediately upon hire. The law applies to all employers by 2022 regardless of size and includes provisions for use related to personal or family illness, domestic abuse, and public health emergencies such as COVID-19 [11].

Conversely, some states like Delaware and West Virginia do not have any state or local mandatory sick leave laws, meaning employers in these states are not required by law to provide paid or unpaid sick leave [2][7]. Additionally, certain states, such as Louisiana, prohibit local governments from establishing mandatory minimum sick leave requirements for private employers, effectively limiting sick leave mandates to the state level or none at all [5].

In summary, businesses must comply with mandatory sick leave laws if they operate in states with such requirements, which are increasingly common but not universal. Employers should stay informed about their specific state and local laws, as these can differ widely and impact obligations regarding paid sick leave [1][3].

optimizations.query: current trends in worker benefits 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, a significant trend in worker benefits is the expansion and formalization of paid sick leave policies, exemplified by legislation such as Colorado's Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA). This law mandates that employers provide up to 48 hours of earned paid sick leave annually, accrued from the first day of employment, with provisions allowing leave for personal or family illness, preventive care, and recovery from domestic abuse or public health emergencies like COVID-19. Employers must allow flexible use of this leave without requiring employees to find replacements and must carry over unused leave up to 48 hours to the next year, though payout at separation is not required. Additionally, during public health emergencies, employees are entitled to supplemental paid sick leave of at least 80 hours, covering isolation, treatment, and caregiving needs related to communicable illnesses. Employers are also prohibited from demanding documentation for such leave and must maintain records accordingly [11].

This trend reflects a broader movement toward enhancing worker protections and flexibility in response to ongoing public health concerns and evolving workforce expectations. It underscores the increasing importance of comprehensive paid sick leave as a core benefit, supporting employee well-being and public health while accommodating diverse personal and family care needs [11].

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.

Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;

Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.

The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.

(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or

(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;

optimizations.query: what are the new sick leave requirements for businesses in colorado?
optimizations.final_answer:
Colorado's new sick leave requirements, established under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), mandate that all employers provide paid sick leave to employees starting January 1, 2022, regardless of business size. Previously, only employers with 16 or more employees were required to comply beginning January 1, 2021 [11][6]. 

Employees accrue paid sick leave at a rate of at least one hour for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours (six days) per year, though employers may offer more. Accrual begins immediately upon hire, and employees can use leave as soon as it is accrued [11][4]. Employers may also front-load the full amount of leave at the start of the year instead of tracking accrual [11].

Paid sick leave can be used for the employee’s own physical or mental illness, injury, or preventive care; to care for a family member with similar health needs; or for reasons related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment, including seeking medical attention, counseling, legal services, or relocation [11]. Additionally, leave can be taken due to public health emergencies, such as COVID-19, including self-isolation, care for a family member, or when a child’s school or care provider is closed [11].

Employees must take leave in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments, and employers cannot require employees to find a replacement worker as a condition for taking leave. Requests can be made orally, in writing, or electronically, and while employers may have reasonable notice policies, they cannot deny leave for noncompliance with such policies [11].

Unused paid sick leave can be carried over to the next year, up to 48 hours, but employers may limit annual use to 48 hours. Employers are not required to pay out unused leave upon separation but must reinstate unused leave if the employee is rehired within six months [11].

In the event of a public health emergency, employees are entitled to a supplemental one-time grant of paid sick leave (at least 80 hours for full-time employees) for COVID-19-related reasons, which employers must provide in addition to accrued leave. This supplemental leave can be used without requiring documentation and remains available up to four weeks after the emergency ends [11].

Employers must retain records documenting hours worked, sick leave accrued, and used for at least two years and notify employees in writing of their paid sick leave rights [10][11].

In summary, Colorado’s new sick leave law significantly expands paid sick leave protections to all employees statewide, with detailed provisions on accrual, usage, carryover, and supplemental leave during public health emergencies [11][4][6].

(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.

(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.

(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;

(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;

Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.

In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.

The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.

Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.  
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.

### Employee Handbook Templates and Compliance Support  
To assist employers in complying with the HFWA and managing paid sick leave policies effectively, a variety of employee handbook templates are available. Employers may purchase, download, or create customized employee handbooks that incorporate HFWA provisions, including accrual rates, permissible leave uses, notification requirements, and anti-retaliation protections.

Available templates range from fully customizable documents to state-specific and compliance-focused handbooks designed to meet Colorado’s unique requirements under the HFWA. Pricing for these templates varies widely, from affordable one-time purchases to subscription-based services that include ongoing updates and legal review.  

Using purchased or professionally developed templates offers several benefits: they help ensure employer policies align with current legal requirements, reduce the risk of non-compliance, and provide clear, consistent guidance to employees regarding their rights and responsibilities under the HFWA. These templates can also streamline HR management by integrating paid sick leave policies with other workplace rules and procedures.  

When selecting a handbook template, employers should consider factors such as the template’s currency with Colorado law, ease of customization, clarity of language, and inclusion of all HFWA-required elements. Employers are encouraged to review and update their handbooks regularly to reflect any changes in the law or workplace practices. Implementing these templates effectively involves training HR personnel and communicating policy updates clearly to employees to ensure understanding and compliance.

optimizations.query: current colorado labor laws 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado labor laws include several key provisions governing wages, overtime, and paid sick leave. The Colorado Overtime and Minimum Pay Standards (COMPS) Order, effective since March 16, 2020, regulates overtime pay and minimum wage standards in the state [1]. Additionally, Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which requires employers to provide paid sick leave to employees. Under the HFWA, employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually, with the ability to carry over unused leave to the next year, though employers may cap usage at 48 hours per year [11]. Employers with 16 or more employees have been required to comply since January 1, 2021, and all employers regardless of size since January 1, 2022 [11].

Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for their own or a family member’s illness, medical care, preventive care, or recovery from domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment. The law also provides for paid sick leave related to public health emergencies, including COVID-19, allowing supplemental leave of up to 80 hours for full-time employees to cover isolation, care, or closure of schools or childcare [11]. Employers cannot require employees to find replacement workers as a condition for taking leave, and requests can be made orally or in writing [11]. The Colorado Division of Labor Standards and Statistics enforces these requirements [11].

These laws reflect Colorado’s commitment to protecting workers’ rights to fair wages, overtime compensation, and paid sick leave, ensuring a supportive workplace environment in 2023 [1][11].

Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.

The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.

In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;

The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.

An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.

Employers may purchase, download, or create customized employee handbooks that incorporate HFWA provisions, including accrual rates, permissible leave uses, notification requirements, and anti-retaliation protections.

Available templates range from fully customizable documents to state-specific and compliance-focused handbooks designed to meet Colorado’s unique requirements under the HFWA. Pricing for these templates varies widely, from affordable one-time purchases to subscription-based services that include ongoing updates and legal review.  

Using purchased or professionally developed templates offers several benefits: they help ensure employer policies align with current legal requirements, reduce the risk of non-compliance, and provide clear, consistent guidance to employees regarding their rights and responsibilities under the HFWA. These templates can also streamline HR management by integrating paid sick leave policies with other workplace rules and procedures.

Colorado’s paid sick leave law, known as the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA, SB20-205), requires most private employers to provide paid sick leave to employees, with specific provisions based on employer size and effective dates. Employers with 16 or more employees had to comply starting January 1, 2021, while all employers regardless of size must comply from January 1, 2022 [11].

Employers may also front-load the full amount at the start of the year instead of accrual. Exempt employees accrue leave based on their normal workweek hours [11].

Employees can use accrued paid sick leave for a variety of reasons, including their own or a family member’s mental or physical illness, injury, or preventive care; recovery from or services related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; and absences due to public health emergencies such as COVID-19, including quarantine, diagnosis, treatment, or caring for a child or family member affected by school or care closures [11].

Leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments. Employers cannot require employees to find a replacement worker as a condition for taking leave. Requests can be made orally, in writing, or electronically, and while employers may have reasonable notice policies, they cannot deny leave for failure to comply with such policies [11].

Unused paid sick leave can be carried over to the next year, up to 48 hours, but employers may limit annual use to 48 hours. There is no requirement to pay out unused leave upon separation, but if an employee is rehired within six months, the employer must reinstate unused accrued leave from prior employment [11].

In addition to regular accrual, the HFWA mandates supplemental paid sick leave during public health emergencies, such as the COVID-19 pandemic. This supplemental leave provides up to 80 hours (or the employee’s scheduled/average hours over 14 days if less than 40 hours per week) for reasons related to communicable illnesses causing the emergency, including self-isolation, symptoms, diagnosis, preventive care, or caring for affected family members. Employers may count other paid time off toward this supplemental leave and cannot require documentation. This leave can be used up to four weeks after the public health emergency ends [11].

The Colorado Division of Labor Standards and Statistics enforces the HFWA and will issue rules regarding compensation and accrual [11].

In summary, Colorado’s paid sick leave law mandates broad coverage for private sector employees, immediate accrual and use, multiple qualifying reasons including public health emergencies, carryover provisions, and supplemental leave during declared emergencies, making it one of the more comprehensive state paid sick leave laws in the U.S. [2][3][11].

optimizations.query: overview of new sick leave laws in colorado 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado's sick leave laws continue to be governed primarily by the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which requires employers to provide paid sick leave to employees. Under the HFWA, employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year, with some employers opting to provide more. Employees can begin using accrued sick leave immediately upon hire and may use it for their own or a family member’s illness, medical care, preventive care, or recovery from domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment. Additionally, leave can be taken if a public health emergency causes business or school closures affecting the employee or their family [11].

Employers with 16 or more employees have been required to comply since January 1, 2021, while all employers regardless of size must comply starting January 1, 2022. The law also mandates a one-time supplemental leave grant of up to 80 hours during a public health emergency, such as COVID-19, to cover self-isolation, care for family members, or childcare disruptions. This supplemental leave can be used without requiring documentation and extends up to four weeks after the emergency ends. Employers may allow leave to be taken in increments smaller than one hour and cannot require employees to find replacement workers as a condition for taking leave. Unused sick leave can be carried over to the next year, but employers may cap annual use at 48 hours. There is no requirement to pay out unused sick leave upon separation, but if an employee is rehired within six months, their accrued leave must be reinstated [11].

Furthermore, Colorado is set to implement a Paid Family and Medical Leave (PFML) program starting January 1, 2024, which will provide additional leave benefits beyond the HFWA [9]. This new program will complement existing sick leave laws by offering broader family and medical leave protections.

Overall, Colorado’s 2023 sick leave laws emphasize employee access to paid sick leave for a wide range of health and family-related reasons, with strong provisions for public health emergencies and protections against retaliation [11][9].

Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.

Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.

The employee:

(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or

(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;

optimizations.query: how does paid sick leave work in colorado for small businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
In Colorado, paid sick leave for small businesses is governed by the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which requires all employers, regardless of size, to provide paid sick leave starting January 1, 2022 [11]. Employees accrue paid sick leave at a rate of one hour for every 30 hours worked, up to a cap of 48 hours per year, though employers may set a higher limit if desired [6][10][11]. Small businesses with fewer than 10 employees are not exempt; they must comply with these requirements as of 2022 [6][11].

Employees begin accruing paid sick leave immediately upon hire and can use it as soon as it is accrued [11]. Paid sick leave can be used for a variety of reasons, including the employee’s own illness or injury, medical diagnosis or treatment, preventive care, caring for a family member with similar health needs, or situations related to domestic abuse or public health emergencies such as COVID-19 [11]. Leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments [11].

Employers cannot require employees to find a replacement worker as a condition for taking paid sick leave, and requests for leave can be made orally, in writing, or electronically [11]. Unused paid sick leave can be carried over to the next year, but employers may limit the amount of leave taken annually to 48 hours [11]. There is no obligation for employers to pay out unused sick leave upon separation, but if an employee is rehired within six months, any unused leave must be reinstated [11].

Additionally, during public health emergencies, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, employees are entitled to supplemental paid sick leave of up to 80 hours if they work full-time, or a prorated amount if part-time, to cover reasons related to the emergency, including self-isolation, care for family members, or childcare due to closures [11]. Employers may count accrued leave toward this supplemental leave and cannot require documentation for its use [11].

In summary, Colorado’s paid sick leave law mandates that small businesses provide paid sick leave accrued at one hour per 30 hours worked, with a 48-hour annual cap, usable immediately for a broad range of health and safety reasons, including public health emergencies [6][10][11].

The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.

Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.

Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.

The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.

An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;

(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;

To assist employers in complying with the HFWA and managing paid sick leave policies effectively, a variety of employee handbook templates are available. Employers may purchase, download, or create customized employee handbooks that incorporate HFWA provisions, including accrual rates, permissible leave uses, notification requirements, and anti-retaliation protections.  

Common sources for purchasing these templates include online legal template providers such as LegalZoom and Rocket Lawyer, HR software platforms like BambooHR and Gusto, and specialized compliance services offered by firms including Jackson Lewis. Available templates range from fully customizable documents to state-specific and compliance-focused handbooks designed to meet Colorado’s unique requirements under the HFWA. Pricing for these templates varies widely, from affordable one-time purchases to subscription-based services that include ongoing updates and legal review.

Employers are encouraged to review and update their handbooks regularly to reflect any changes in the law or workplace practices. Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.
