optimizations.query: overview of colorado paid sick leave law for small businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
Colorado’s paid sick leave law, known as the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA, SB20-205), requires all employers, regardless of size, to provide paid sick leave to employees starting January 1, 2022. Employers with 16 or more employees had an earlier compliance date of January 1, 2021 [11].

Under the HFWA, employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year, though employers may set a higher limit. Accrual begins immediately upon hire, and employees can use leave as soon as it is accrued. Employers may also front-load the full amount of leave at the start of the year to meet accrual requirements [11].

Employees may use paid sick leave for their own or a family member’s mental or physical illness, injury, preventive care, or medical diagnosis and treatment. Leave can also be used for reasons related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment, including seeking medical attention, counseling, legal services, or relocation. Additionally, leave is available if a public health emergency causes closure of the employee’s workplace or their child’s school or care facility, requiring the employee to care for the child [11].

Leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments. Employers cannot require employees to find a replacement worker as a condition for taking leave. Requests can be made orally, in writing, or electronically, and employers may have reasonable notice policies but cannot deny leave for noncompliance with such policies [11].

Unused paid sick leave can be carried over to the next year, up to 48 hours, but employers may limit annual use to 48 hours. The HFWA does not require payout of unused leave upon separation, but if an employee is rehired within six months, accrued leave must be reinstated [11].

In addition to regular accrual, the HFWA mandates a one-time supplemental paid sick leave grant of at least 80 hours for employees working 40 or more hours per week (pro-rated for part-time employees) during a declared public health emergency. This supplemental leave covers reasons such as self-isolation, seeking diagnosis or treatment, preventive care related to the emergency illness, or caring for family members affected by the emergency [11].

The Colorado Division of Labor Standards and Statistics enforces the HFWA and provides rules on compensation and accrual. Employers and employees can access the full law and guidance through the Colorado General Assembly and U.S. Department of Labor websites [11].

In summary, Colorado’s paid sick leave law applies to all small businesses, mandates accrual and use of paid sick leave with broad qualifying reasons, includes protections during public health emergencies, and provides clear rules on accrual, use, carryover, and reinstatement of leave [11].

(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

The HFWA was enacted by the Colorado General Assembly, the state’s legislative body responsible for creating laws. For more information on the legislative process or to view the full text of the HFWA and related statutes, employers and employees can visit the Colorado General Assembly’s official website at [https://leg.colorado.gov](https://leg.colorado.gov).  

For federal employee rights information, including guidance on federal labor laws and paid sick leave provisions, employers and employees may also consult the U.S. Department of Labor’s Employee Rights pages at [https://www.dol.gov/general/topic/workhours/paidleave](https://www.dol.gov/general/topic/workhours/paidleave). These resources provide comprehensive information on federal leave laws, compliance assistance, and official notices that complement state requirements such as the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.

When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.

In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.

(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;

Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

The HFWA was enacted by the Colorado General Assembly, the state’s legislative body responsible for creating laws. For more information on the legislative process or to view the full text of the HFWA and related statutes, employers and employees can visit the Colorado General Assembly’s official website at [https://leg.colorado.gov](https://leg.colorado.gov).  

For federal employee rights information, including guidance on federal labor laws and paid sick leave provisions, employers and employees may also consult the U.S. Department of Labor’s Employee Rights pages at [https://www.dol.gov/general/topic/workhours/paidleave](https://www.dol.gov/general/topic/workhours/paidleave). These resources provide comprehensive information on federal leave laws, compliance assistance, and official notices that complement state requirements such as the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.  

### Recordkeeping  
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.  

### Anti-Retaliation  
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.  
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.  
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.

### Employee Handbook Templates and Compliance Support  
To assist employers in complying with the HFWA and managing paid sick leave policies effectively, a variety of employee handbook templates are available. Employers may purchase, download, or create customized employee handbooks that incorporate HFWA provisions, including accrual rates, permissible leave uses, notification requirements, and anti-retaliation protections.  
These templates help ensure that employer policies align with current legal requirements and provide clear guidance to employees regarding their rights and responsibilities under the HFWA. Utilizing such templates can streamline HR management, reduce compliance risks, and facilitate consistent communication of paid sick leave policies.  
Jackson Lewis attorneys are available to assist employers in their compliance efforts. If you have questions about the HFWA, including the poster and employee notice requirements, revisions to language in employee handbooks, implementation strategies, or any other workplace issues, please contact the Jackson Lewis attorney with whom you regularly work.  

Common sources for purchasing these templates include online legal template providers such as LegalZoom and Rocket Lawyer, HR software platforms like BambooHR and Gusto, and specialized compliance services offered by firms including Jackson Lewis. Available templates range from fully customizable documents to state-specific and compliance-focused handbooks designed to meet Colorado’s unique requirements under the HFWA. Pricing for these templates varies widely, from affordable one-time purchases to subscription-based services that include ongoing updates and legal review.  

Using purchased or professionally developed templates offers several benefits: they help ensure employer policies align with current legal requirements, reduce the risk of non-compliance, and provide clear, consistent guidance to employees regarding their rights and responsibilities under the HFWA. These templates can also streamline HR management by integrating paid sick leave policies with other workplace rules and procedures.  

When selecting a handbook template, employers should consider factors such as the template’s currency with Colorado law, ease of customization, clarity of language, and inclusion of all HFWA-required elements. Employers are encouraged to review and update their handbooks regularly to reflect any changes in the law or workplace practices. Implementing these templates effectively involves training HR personnel and communicating policy updates clearly to employees to ensure understanding and compliance.  

### Employee Rights Compliance Software  
In addition to handbook templates, employers may also utilize employee rights compliance software to manage adherence to laws like the HFWA more efficiently. These software solutions help automate tracking of paid sick leave accrual, usage, and carryover, generate required notices and reports, and maintain accurate records to meet HFWA’s documentation requirements.  

Types of compliance software include standalone paid sick leave management tools, integrated HR management systems (HRMS), and broader workforce management platforms that incorporate leave tracking alongside scheduling, payroll, and benefits administration. Popular providers offering such solutions include ADP, Paychex, Zenefits, and BambooHR, which often provide Colorado-specific compliance features or customizable modules to address state law nuances.  

The benefits of using compliance software include reducing administrative burden, minimizing human error, ensuring timely and accurate employee notifications, and facilitating audit readiness. These tools can also help employers stay updated on regulatory changes by providing alerts and automatic policy updates.  

When selecting compliance software, employers should evaluate factors such as ease of use, integration capabilities with existing HR and payroll systems, scalability for workforce size, and the availability of customer support and legal updates. Implementing these tools effectively requires proper training for HR staff and clear communication with employees about how leave requests and tracking will be managed through the software.  

These compliance software solutions complement employee handbook templates by providing practical tools to implement and enforce the policies outlined in handbooks, ensuring consistent application of HFWA requirements across the workforce. Employers are encouraged to consult with legal counsel, such as Jackson Lewis attorneys, to assist in selecting and implementing software solutions that align with HFWA requirements and other applicable labor laws.

### Employee Benefits Management Platforms for Small Businesses  
In addition to compliance software and handbook templates, small businesses may benefit from using employee benefits management platforms designed to streamline administration of paid sick leave alongside other employee benefits. These platforms vary in scope and typically fall into three categories: standalone benefits administration platforms, integrated HR and payroll systems, and all-in-one HR suites that combine benefits management with broader human resources functions.  

Key features small businesses should look for in benefits management platforms include ease of use, seamless integration with existing payroll and HR systems, compliance support tailored to state-specific laws like the HFWA, employee self-service portals for benefits enrollment and management, automated eligibility tracking, contribution management, and robust reporting tools. These features help ensure accurate administration of paid sick leave and other benefits while reducing administrative workload.  

Popular and reputable benefits management providers well-suited for small businesses include Gusto, Zenefits, Justworks, and Paycor. These platforms offer user-friendly interfaces, scalable solutions that grow with the business, and compliance tools that help employers meet requirements such as those mandated by the HFWA. Many also provide additional HR services, including onboarding, time tracking, and performance management, creating a comprehensive solution for small business needs.  

The benefits of using these platforms include reducing administrative burdens, improving accuracy in benefits administration, enhancing employee engagement through accessible self-service options, and ensuring compliance with complex laws like the HFWA. By automating many manual processes, these platforms help minimize errors and facilitate timely updates to policies and benefits offerings.  

When selecting and implementing a benefits management platform, employers should consider factors such as the platform’s scalability, customer support quality, ease of integration with existing systems, and the ability to customize benefits offerings to align with HFWA and other regulatory requirements. Effective implementation involves training HR staff, communicating clearly with employees about how to access and manage their benefits, and regularly reviewing platform performance to ensure ongoing compliance and user satisfaction. Employers are encouraged to consult with legal and HR professionals to ensure the chosen platform supports comprehensive compliance efforts and aligns with organizational goals.  

### Employee Management Software for HR  
Beyond compliance-specific tools, many employers utilize comprehensive employee management software to handle a wide range of HR functions, including employee records management, recruitment, performance evaluation, scheduling, time tracking, and payroll processing. These platforms help centralize HR operations, improve efficiency, and support compliance with laws such as the HFWA by integrating paid sick leave tracking with broader workforce management.  

Types of employee management software include Human Resource Information Systems (HRIS), Human Capital Management (HCM) platforms, and Workforce Management Systems (WMS). These solutions often feature modules for applicant tracking, onboarding, employee self-service, benefits administration, time and attendance, and performance management.  

Popular providers in this space include Workday, ADP Workforce Now, BambooHR, Paycor, and Kronos. These platforms vary in complexity and pricing, catering to businesses of different sizes and industries. Many offer cloud-based solutions with mobile access, enabling HR teams and employees to manage information conveniently and securely.  

The benefits of employee management software include streamlined HR workflows, improved data accuracy, enhanced employee engagement through self-service portals, and better compliance management by automating recordkeeping and reporting. Integration with payroll and benefits systems further reduces administrative burden and helps ensure consistent application of policies like those required by the HFWA.  

When selecting employee management software, employers should assess factors such as the software’s feature set, ease of use, integration capabilities with existing systems, scalability, data security, and vendor support. Implementation should include thorough training for HR staff and clear communication with employees about new processes and tools. Employers are advised to work with legal and HR consultants to ensure the software supports compliance with the HFWA and other applicable labor laws while meeting organizational needs.  

### Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated  
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.
